entry.title: A simplified approach to choosing between S/4HANA Public Cloud vs S/4HANA Private Cloud
entry.content:
One of the fundamental decisions that organisations are facing as they plan their transition to Cloud ERP, is the deployment option to choose. In SAP terms the question becomes: Would S/4HANA Public Cloud or S/4HANA Private Cloud be the better choice?

At high level, S/4HANA Public Cloud is a "ready-to-run" solution prioritizing standardization and deployment speed, while S/4HANA Private Cloud is a "tailored-to-fit" solution enabling flexibility and customization. In reality, the selection between the two is more complex with different parameters to consider. This article aims to ease the decision process through a simplified approach.

The right deployment option could, and most often should, be subject to a series of workshops and careful assessment of an organisation's specific needs. Still, experience from customer engagements has enabled me to develop a simplified approach which helps provide initial steering.

Overall, where possible, S/4HANA Public Cloud should be the ultimate destination. This due to its unique qualities, including faster access to innovation, a simpler Cloud operating model and reduced Total Cost of Ownership (TCO). On the flip side, Public Cloud also comes with limitations as compared to S/4HANA Private Cloud. These include a narrower implementation scope, reduced system control and the need to leave customisations and certain data behind.

To simplify the decision, as a rule of thumb an organisation should opt for S/4HANA Public Cloud if the following three elements match their needs:

  • S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation scope. Public Cloud offers  broad functionality covering the needs of most organizations and is becoming constantly richer in scope. Still, some functionality such as industry-specific scenarios may be unique to Private Cloud. The way to confirm that Public Cloud vs Private Cloud is fit for purpose is by completing the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment in collaboration with SAP or your Partner.
  • New implementation as migration option. A migration to Public Cloud can be completed only via a new implementation, while a migration to Private Cloud can also be completed via a system conversion or Selective Data transition for organisations on a legacy SAP ERP system. If you are new to SAP, then a new implementation is your clear way forward. If you are moving from a legacy SAP ERP system though, then it is key to validate that a new implementation is right for you. A new implementation requires that custom code and custom processes from your legacy SAP ERP system are left behind - which could actually be an opportunity for moving to a Clean Core and reinventing business processes using SAP's Best Practices. A new implementation also requires that previous transactional data aka closed items are left behind e.g. archived, otherwise maintained in the legacy ERP system (online as read-only or offline as a backup/image). Unless there is a specific need to bring closed items to the new Cloud ERP environment, leaving these behind helps run a lighter, easier to maintain and more cost-efficient system.
  • Public Cloud Operating model. Public Cloud is equivalent to SaaS, as opposed to Private Cloud which is similar to IaaS/PaaS. This means that Public Cloud is highly standardised, enabling rapid innovation at a lower TCO, offering a Clean Core and SAPâ€‘controlled operations and allowing the customer to focus on what matters to them most. It comes with Application Management Services included, therefore, among others, SAP is taking care of  application management including release updates and Middleware. Still, in Public Cloud, extensibility options are limited (classic ABAP extensibility not possible), the customer has no control over release upgrades (these are mandatory without the option to postpone and with a time-restricted regression testing window), and has no control over infrastructure choices either (no Hyperscaler selection). If the organisation has a particular requirement for any of these or for an overall operating model of shared responsibility with SAP, then Private Cloud might be better suited.

    While the above three elements focus mostly on the technical aspects of the deployment option decision, it comes without saying that the company's culture is also a major decisive factor. The appetite to reimagine processes and outsource a large part of IT operations to the software vendor while re-focusing on innovation activities, are of paramount importance for a Public Cloud deployment.

    All that said, the value and fit of Private Cloud for certain organisations should not be overlooked. Many enterprises, especially those with regulatory constraints, multiâ€‘layered integrations, high customisation, heavy data volumes, or deep industry-specific implementation scope, continue to find Private Cloud more practical and in cases the only suitable option.

    To summarise, if you are an organisation planning a transition to SAPâ€™s Cloud ERP and considering your deployment option, your actionable next steps are as follows: complete the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment to confirm whether the scope of S/4HANA Public Cloud matches your functionality needs, evaluate whether a new implementation vs system conversion is fit for purpose, and assess whether the Public Cloud operating model suits you. If the answer to all three questions is yes, and you establish the right company culture, then lead with S/4HANA Public Cloud. Otherwise, in case of unique requirements and a more complex landscape, S/4HANA Private Cloud might be a better fit. 

    Disclaimer: The approach suggested in this article reflects my views based on experience from working with different organizations, rather than SAP's official views. It aims to provide simplified guidelines and initial steering, but does not replace the need for more thorough assessment.

entry.title: Re: exchange rate P for standard cost accounting
entry.content:
Dear @makoto_kasuya91,

In Public Cloud a material/standard cost estimate will not use exchange rate type P just because you maintained rates for type P. You must also ensure that product costing is actually selecting exchange rate type P via the planning/category logic used by the valuation variant

Points to check:

Point 1.

In Public Cloud the exchange rate type for material cost estimate / costing run is determined from the Planning Category and its mapping to an exchange rate type. SAP documents the logic as:

  • Get exchange rate type from Planning Category PLN, configured in 101970 Maintain Category for Planning
  • If nothing is found, system falls back to exchange rate type P

So if you see M being used, it usually means your PLN planning category is mapped to M or you are looking at a different conversion, see point 4

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3667170

Point 2.

In your CBC:

  • Open Maintain Category for Planning (101970)

 

  • Locate planning category PLN
  • Ensure Exchange Rate Type = P
  • Save

SAP explicitly points to 101970 as the place where PLN <-> exchange rate type is maintained

SAP Note and SAP Help below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3513695

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3482860

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/72041b59d4d6413f9c8cdf92bc2ccc7e.html

Summary:

  1. In CBC: 101970, confirm PLN ->P mapping
  2. In Currency Exchange Rates app maintain type P rates for all required currency pairs and for the date used by the cost estimate
  3. Re-run the cost estimate. Existing saved estimates wonâ€™t retroactively recalculate

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit â€“ Migrate Directly from SAP System â€“ The Transfer List
entry.content:
Hi all, 

The migration approach Migrate Data Directly from SAP System uses APIs to write data to the SAP S/4HANA target system.

The source data is passed to the parameters of the target API, and the API uses that data to create data in the target SAP S/4HANA system. However, this data can be first modified by field mapping rules (such as mapping rules or source code rules).

Until now, it was not possible to view the exact data that the API uses to create data in the target SAP S/4HANA system.

In the Migrate Your Data app, you can now use the transfer list to view the data that the target API uses to create data in SAP S/4HANA, including the results of all used mapping rules.

Viewing the transfer list can be beneficial if you want to troubleshoot the simulation or migration process. For example, you can analyze the transfer list to determine whether an issue occurs with the target API or if it is a structure or field mapping issue. 

 Where can I find the transfer list?

The transfer list is available with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition 2602.

In the Migrate Your Data app, navigate to the Migration Object Instances screen, select the relevant migration object instance and then choose the Transfer List button.

Note that this feature is only available for the migration approach Migrate Data Directly from SAP System. 

Once the simulation process or migration process is complete for a migration object instance, you can view the transfer list for that instance. If a migration object has multiple transfer steps, a transfer list will be available for each processed step.  

Example

On the Transfer List screen, you can see instance ZRH0000011 for the migration object Customer. This migration object has four transfer steps. The first step CMD_MIG_BP_CVI_CREATE has been simulated successfully for the instance. This means that the transfer list is available for this step. On the left-hand side of the screen, you can view detailed information about the import parameters of step API CMD_MIG_BP_CVI_CREATE.

If you select an import parameter, the system displays the input data for the parameter on the right-hand side of the screen.  

You can use this information, for example, to determine whether an issue occurs with the target API or if it is a structure or field mapping issue.  

We are happy to hear your feedback!  

All the best for your project! 

Philipp

entry.title: Can ExcelAdapter Handle Custom Path in SAP PaPM Cloud integration?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!ðŸ˜Š

In the earlier SAP Community blogpost SAP PaPM Cloud Integration with Microsoft Excel, we looked at how SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud leverages HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI) with the ExcelAdapter to consume Excel files.

By default, ExcelAdapter only looks for files in the <DPAGENT_DIR>/excel folder. This setup is OK most of the time but what happens when the business wants to make some changes in the location of their Excel filesâ€¦ may it be because of the main drive running out of storage space or reorganizing the folder structure or a cleaner setup. Suddenly, the setup feels more like a limitation than a convenience.

And hereâ€™s the catch: if you try to point the Remote Source Configuration to a custom folder, youâ€™ll hit an error just like in the screenshot below.

Does that mean you're stuck on using the default directory? Not quite because we have a workaround. The trick is to use a symbolic link (symlink). In this workaround, the ExcelAdapter will think that it will pull the Excel files from <DPAGENT_DIR>/excel, but in reality, your files are located in other directory.

Let's break it down on how we can achieve this:

Prerequisites:

  • You have an Administrator access in the OS
  • Ensure that the DP Agent Service User have access to the directory to avoid any issue as per SAP Note 3303503

For Windows:

1. Open command prompt as Administrator using the DP Agent Service User and go to <DPAGENT_DIR> directory

2. Enter command: mklink /D excel <Target Directory where your Excel Files are Stored>

For Linux/Unix:

Use the ln-s command: 

ln -s <Target Directory where Excel Files are Stored> <DPAGENT_DIR>/excel

This workaround gives you the flexibility to scale storage, keep things tidy, and adapt to changing business needsâ€”all while staying within ExcelAdapterâ€™s rules.

Have you tried this workaround yourself? Share your story in the comments. ðŸ˜Š

entry.title: Re: entries of 2l and ol ledger difference
entry.content:
Dear all,

SAP S/4HANA behaves this way and, in general, it does not require a correction but rather an overall reconciliation and configuration check.

Ledgers 0L and 2L for the same material and company code are valuated independently. Differences in currency types, exchange rates, Material Ledger price calculation, or rounding can lead to small amount variances.

To address this overall, you should:

  1. Check the currency configuration of the ledgers
    Confirm the currency types and exchange rate types assigned to 0L and 2L. If the business requires identical valuation, the ledger design must be aligned accordingly.
  2. Analyze Material Ledger prices per ledger
    Review prices and settlements per ledger (price and FX differences). If actual costing is active, such differences are expected and correct.
  3. Review rounding impacts
    Small differences may result from rounding at line-item or ledger level and should be reconciled rather than adjusted.

Please feel free to reach out if the differences are material or increasing over time.

Regards

Maciej

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud: How can I compare variable values?
entry.content:
Yj,

var border = "0010000000";  This variable is of type string and you are trying to do an integer operation  > on it which would not work.

Please convert both both cust and border explicitly to number/integer and then try the comparison. You can use the below

ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(stringVariable)

border_num=ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(border); 

cust_num=ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(cust);

if (cust_num > border_num) {
Application.setPageVisible("Page_7", false);
} else {
Application.setPageVisible("Page_7", true);
}

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: SAP Task Center Updates: Global Settings in the Administration App
entry.content:
In this series of blog posts, weâ€™ll walk you through the latest updates in the SAP Task Center Administration app, each one designed to simplify the administrative experience and save valuable time.  

Today, weâ€™re focusing on one of the most exciting updates, the new Global Settings tab, which significantly enhances the way administrators manage global configurations for the SAP Task Center Web app.  

The Purpose of Global Settings in SAP Task Center

Global settings are essential for maintaining consistency in SAP Task Center. They allow administrators to manage key configurations that apply to all task providers, ensuring uniformity across the SAP Task Center Web app, and contribute to a unified user experience across all task providers. These settings impact things like supported languages, enablement of the Outbox feature, and the URL used in email notifications. 

The Old Process of Updating Global Settings

Before the introduction of the Global Settings tab, administrators had to manage the global settings destination in the SAP BTP cockpit. This meant navigating to the Cloud Foundry subaccount, locating the Task_Center_global_settings destination, and updating specific values, according to the documentation. Any corrections required repeating the entire process, making it time-consuming and error prone.

The New Global Settings Tab

Now, with the introduction of the Global Settings tab in the SAP Task Center Admin app, administrators can manage these settings more easily and efficiently. The new process has been designed to save time and reduce complexity, allowing administrators to focus on higher-priority tasks.

  1. Centralized Management 
    The Global Settings tab is now located directly within the SAP Task Center Administration app, providing a single, central place for administrators to access and maintain all global settings for all task providers.
  2. Seamless Integration with SAP BTP
    While the Task_Center_global_settings destination is still necessary, it can now be managed directly from the Global Settings tab in the Admin app. Any changes made in the Global Settings tab are automatically synced with the destination in the SAP BTP cockpit, ensuring consistency without any extra manual effort.
    If you havenâ€™t set up SAP Task Center yet, we recommend following the automatic setup, so all destinations, including Task_Center_global_settings, are created for you by the booster. This way you can directly update respective properties from the Global Settings tab. 
  3. Simplified Workflow
    Administrators can configure and validate global settings more quickly, with fewer steps and less context switching. Built-in validation immediately highlights configuration issues, helping prevent errors, reduce trial-and-error, and ensuring that changes are correct before they take effect.

Interested in the UI? Take a look at the Global Settings tab.

This is an overview of the newly introduced Global Settings tab in the SAP Task Center Administration app.

The following demo shows how global settings can be configured directly in the SAP Task Center Administration app.

 

This update not only simplifies the administration tasks but also provides a more intuitive user experience that reduces errors and saves valuable time of the SAP Task Center administrators.

In our upcoming posts, we will cover other exciting updates to the SAP Task Center Administration app.

Stay tuned and stay efficient,

Your SAP Task Center Team

entry.title: Enabling External Workflows for Documents in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Summary

Beside the already available approval procedure available for documents, weâ€™re excited to introduce external workflow integration for Documents in SAP Cloud ALM, enabling organizations to seamlessly connect document management with powerful workflow and approval solutions such as SAP Build Process Automation (BPA).

From Document to Approval â€“ Automatically

When working with documents in SAP Cloud ALM, approvals are often a critical step. With external workflow integration enabled, a custom workflow is automatically triggered as soon as a user selects â€œStart Approvalâ€ in the Documents app.

Behind the scenes, SAP Cloud ALM hands over the approval request to SAP Build Process Automation, where approvers receive their tasks directly in BPA My Inbox.

 The model below illustrates the operational flow and overall functionality.

 

Seamless approval state synchronization

The integration ensures that document approval states in SAP Cloud ALM always reflect the current approval situation:

  • Approval Pendingâ†’ Document status is set to In Review, the document content and external file cannot be edited
  • Approved â†’ Document status is automatically updated to Released
  • Rejected â†’ Document remains In Progress, ready for rework

This tight synchronization removes manual updates, reduces errors, and ensures compliance across teams and projects.

Flexible, customizable workflows

The approval process is fully customizable in SAP Build Process Automation. Organizations can design workflows that include:

  • One or multiple approvers
  • Email notifications
  • Parallel or sequential approvals
  • Additional logic and conditions based on document type or document tagging

Once designed, the workflow is deployed and connected to SAP Cloud ALM using standard APIs and destinationsâ€”no custom coding required.

Configuration

Configuration prerequisites

  • SAP Build Process Automation subscription and the corresponding service instance (including service key) are available.

For more information, see Subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation.

  • SAP Cloud ALM has been provisioned and a Cloud ALM API service instance has been created (including service key)

For more information on how to create a Cloud ALM API service instance, see Enabling SAP Cloud ALM API.

Configuration Overview

1) Create destination from SAP Cloud ALM to SAP Build Process Automation and backwards

Log on to your SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) subaccount where your SAP Cloud ALM tenant is provisioned. Navigate to Connectivity -> Destinations and create a destination with the following parameter:

Parameter Name

Value

Type

HTTP

URL

https://<url>/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances
<url> = URL from the section endpoints -> api of the BPA instance service key

Proxy Type

Internet

Authentication

OAuth2ClientCredentials

Client ID

section uaa->clientid of the BPA instance service key

Client Secret

section uaa->clientsecret of the BPA instance service key

Token Service URL Type

dedicated

Token Service URL

https://<tenant>.authentication.<domain>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
for <tenant> and <domain>, please refer to the URL from the section uaa->url of the BPA instance service key

Create a second one with the following parameter:

Parameter Name

Value

Type

HTTP

URL

https://<your tenant>/api

Proxy Type

Internet

Authentication

OAuth2ClientCredentials

Client ID

section uaa->clientid of the Cloud ALM API instance service key

Client Secret

section uaa->clientsecret of the Cloud ALM API instance service key

Token Service URL Type

dedicated

Token Service URL

https://<tenant>.authentication.<domain>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
for <tenant> and <domain>, please refer to the URL from the section uaa->url of the Cloud ALM API instance service key

Add the following additional properties to the destination:

  • sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled = true
  • sap.processautomation.enabled = true

You can find more information about using the Destination Editor in the Cockpit in Using the Destinations Editor in the Cockpit.

To use this destination in your project, you must add it to your SAP Business Process Automation tenant. Use the Destinations App in the Control Tower.

For further information about managing destinations, see Manage Destinations.

2) Define workflow in SAP Build Process Automation

The following is an example of an approval workflow with an email notification sent to the approver(s) and initiating user of the workflow:

You can download a default workflow as a sample from the link below and import it into your SAP Build Process Automation tenant.

Sample Document Approval Workflow (link)

By extending this default case, you can use a sample workflow with built-in multi-step approval logic. In this workflow, all reviewers are processed sequentially, and every reviewer must approve for the process to continue. You can find this sample here: Sample Document Approval Workflow - exp. multiple level approval

An example demonstrating how to use script tasks to route approvals to reviewers based on document type or tags is available here: Sample Document Approval Workflow - exp. document tag/type routing 

In the Project Properties (available on the project Overview page) create an environment variable. Assign a name and set the type to Destination.

After completing your workflow edits, release the workflow. To make it usable, switch to the released version and choose Deploy.

You will be asked to select an environment. Use the Public Environment.

For more information about environments, see following link.

In the final step, map the Cloud ALM API destination (from SAP Build Process Automation to Cloud ALM) to the environment variable. Use the Destination created in Step 2.

3) Create workflow subscription in SAP Cloud ALM

Create a webhook in External API Management

Log on to your SAP Cloud ALM tenant and navigate to External API Management.

Go to Webhooks Management and choose Add new webhook.

Enter the following data:

Parameter Name

Value

Name

<any name> (identifier to map to the subscription)

Ext Resource Type

Workflow

Destination Source

BTP Destination

Destination Id

<destinationName> (of the destination from SAP Cloud ALM to BPA tenant)

Destination Type

Other

You can find the <destinationName> in the BTP Cockpit where the destination was created in Step 1.

Create a Mapping

Navigate to Mappings Management and choose Add New Mapping.

Enter the following data:

Parameter Name

Value

Description

<any description> (identifier to map to the subscription)

Version

REST API v1

Source

SAP Cloud ALM

Destination

SAP Build Process Automation

Mapping Type

Payload Based

Download the example mapping HERE and copy it into your mapping rules. Adjust the mapping as required. Ensure that the request context matches the input parameters of your workflow. Otherwise, conflicts may occur.

The following document attributes are available:

Parameter Name

Value

id

uuid of the document

title

title of the document

displayId

human readable id of the document

triggeredBy

id of the user that initiated the workflow (started the approval)

ownerId

id of the owner of the document

responsibleId

id of the responsible of the document (if assigned)

typeName

name of the type of the document

statusName

name of the current status the document is in

prorityName

priority of the document

tags

list of tags assigned to the document

projectId

id of the project the document is related to

projectName

name of the project the document is related to

Add a subscription in External API Management

Go to Subscriptions Management and choose Add new subscription.

 Enter the following data:

Parameter Name

Value

Name

<any name>

Description

<any description>

Type

Built-in

Resource Type

Workflow

Webhook

<name of the webhook you created before>

Mapping

<name of the mapping you created before>

Create a User Variable.     

Enter the following data:

Parameter Name

Value

workflowDefinitionId

<workflowId>

reviewedBy

any (optional recipient of the approval task, which is used in the mapping)

To obtain the <workflowId>, log on to your SAP Build Process Automation tenant,navigate to Control Tower -> Environments, select the environment where the workflow is deployed, then go to Processes and Workflows, select your workflow and copy the ID.

To obtain the <environmentId>, log on to your SAP Build Process Automation tenant, navigate to Control Tower -> Environments, select the environment where the workflow is deployed and copy the ID.

4) Assign the Workflow Subscription to a Project

Navigate to a project where you want to use the Document workflow. Open the Subscriptions tab and assign the created workflow subscription to the Document entity:

You are now able to execute test approvals for Documents in SAP Cloud ALM using SAP Build Process Automation.

entry.title: SAP Commerce Cloud Q4 â€˜25 Release Highlights
entry.content:
As we closed out 2025, SAP Commerce Cloud continued its momentum with a powerful set of innovations designed to deliver connected, trusted, and intelligent commerce experiences that drive profitable growth.â€‹ 

Q4 2025 brought impactful enhancements across commerce, data, AI, fulfillment, and user experienceâ€”combined with standout performance results from Cyber Week and recognition once again in the GartnerÂ® Magic Quadrantâ„¢. 

Letâ€™s dive into the top updates from Q4 2025. Join our Q4 2025 Release Highlights webcast and the tech-focused update webcast to stay updated on our latest advancements. 

Learn more about the entire SAP Customer Experience portfolio and the impact of agentic AI.

SAP Commerce Cloud named Leader in Gartner Magic Quadrant for Digital Commerce for 11th year in a row 

SAP has proudly been named a Leader in theâ€¯2025 Gartner Magic Quadrant for Digital Commerce. SAP remains the only vendor consistently recognizedâ€¯11 times since 2014. 

This continued leadership reflects SAP Commerce Cloudâ€™s ability to help organizations scale, innovate, and drive profitable growth in an increasingly competitive market. Key differentiators that set SAP Commerce Cloud apart include its robust B2B selfservice portal with native ERP integration, its broad enterprisegrade capabilities, and its proven support for complex and sophisticated business models. 

SAP Commerce Cloud - Cyber Week Results 

SAP Commerce Cloud delivered outstanding results again during the recent Cyber Week The platform supported $17.8 billion in Gross Merchandise Value (GMV), a 40% year over year increase, and reached a peak throughput of $2.3 billion GMV per minute with 11,000 orders processed per minute. Impressively, all of this was achieved with 100% uptime, underscoring the reliability and resilience of the platform during the highest demand period of the year. These results highlight the strength of SAP Commerce Cloud in helping customers scale to meet shopper expectations during critical moments. 

With agentic AI reshaping how customers discover and shop, explore why â€œ2025 is the Last Year Online Shopping Starts with a Search Bar, Not a Sentence.â€ 

 

Accelerating Customer Value with Enterprise Grade AI Agents 
 
As agentic AI becomes increasingly central to commerce, SAP is expanding its portfolio of intelligent, taskâ€‘oriented agents designed to improve engagement, streamline operations, and enhance service at every stage of the customer journey.  

Below are the latest updates to our AI agent capabilities, beginning with the Digital Service Agent. 

The Digital Service Agent elevates customer self service by delivering fast, accurate support powered by enterprise specific knowledge and data sources. It efficiently resolves complex customer inquiries and can seamlessly hand off conversations to human agents whenever deeper assistance is required, ensuring a smooth and consistent service experience. 
 

Working in tandem with the AI Shopping Agent, the Digital Service Agent unlocks new, end to end use cases that provide even greater value. Together, these agents offer customers unified, intelligent assistance across the entire shopping journeyâ€”from initial product exploration to post purchase supportâ€”improving satisfaction while reducing operational effort. 

Digital Service Agent 

 

Create custom AI agents with Joule Studio AI agent bulder 

 
With the new Joule Studio AI agent builder, you can now create AI agents for SAP Customer Experience applications that retrieve information, execute tasks, and perform autonomous actions using enterprise data from SAP Customer Experience and SAP Knowledge Graph. For example, you can build a returns processing agent that automatically initiates return execution based on insights and recommendations generated by the AI.

Joule Studio, part of SAP Build, offers a powerful lowcode and nocode environment that enables developers to extend Joule capabilities and orchestrate business workflows across both SAP and non SAP systems. From here, teams can easily build, test, and deploy AI agents to enhance operational efficiency and deliver more intelligent customer experiences. 
 
Learn how to activate Joule Studio and start building, testing, and deploying AI Agents. 

 

Joule Studio AI agent builder

 

Turn Live Commerce Data into a Competitive Advantage 

SAP Commerce Cloud Dashboards (Graph Analytics Micro App), is an SAP-certified micro app that is built on SAP Business Technology Platform, providing businesses with instant access to real-time operational insights without the need for complex setup or custom development.  

 

This lightweight yet powerful micro app delivers dynamic dashboards that visualize key commerce metrics including revenue, orders, returns, repeat purchase rates, top performingproducts, and more. By centralizing these insights in a single, intuitive interface, teams can make faster and more informed decisions based on live data. With clearer visibility into trends and performance drivers, businesses can identify growth opportunities, optimize promotions and product strategies, and ultimately boost revenue through data-driven decision making. 

 

Enhance Security and Efficiency with User Management via Cloud Portal API 

User Management via Cloud Portal API enables organizations to manage user roles for an SAP Commerce Cloud environment. By exposing user and role management capabilities through secure APIs, teams can integrate these operations directly into their existing CI/CD and enterprise workflows. This reduces repetitive configuration steps and enhances security and compliance through audit ready role assignments and changes.  

 

Resilient Backup and Recovery with Quick Data Backup 

Quick Data Backup simplifies database protection by providing near-instant backup capabilities and 35-day point in- time recovery across development, stage, and production environments. This solution ensures that businesses can safeguard critical data with confidence and can significantly minimize downtime during incidents. The feature is designed for seamless compatibility with existing workflows, reducing operational friction. With Quick Data Backup, teams gain a reliable, efficient, and resilient foundation for data protection across the entire Commerce Cloud landscape. 

 

Fast In-Memory Cart for High Traffic Commerce 

The Rapid Cart Calculation capability introduces a major performance boost to SAP Commerce Cloud by processing all price and cart calculations directly in server memory. This delivers exceptionally fast response times, especially for high traffic storefronts and scenarios such as product detail page price checks. The in-memory cart not only enhances the customer experience with instant, seamless cart interactions but also significantly reduces backend load, improving overall system scalability and stability. 

 

 This approach supports massive throughputâ€”enabling millions of cart calculation requests per hourâ€”ensuring that even the most demanding commerce environments can maintainconsistent performance during major events like flash sales, seasonal peaks, and promotional campaigns. 

 

Optimize Delivery Performance with Bringg 

Bringg Delivery Management Integrates with SAP Order Management to streamline fulfillment and optimize last mile delivery. With this integration, businesses can offer flexible delivery options, providing customers with real-time tracking updates and proactive notifications across channels. Operationally, automated dispatching reduces manual effort and helps ensure on time delivery, even during peak periods. The result is a faster, more reliable delivery experience that boosts customer satisfaction while improving efficiency and margins. 

 

Assess Your Readiness to Headless Commerce 

The Storefront Maturity Assessment, a free self-service online tool, enables customers to evaluate their organizationâ€™s readiness to transition from Accelerator-based storefronts to modern headless architectures. The tool generates personalized, best practice recommendations tailored to each customerâ€™s starting point, helping teams understand where they excel and where additional preparation or alignment is needed. 

 

 This shared assessment framework allows business and technical stakeholders to align priorities and create a unified transformation roadmap. With actionable insights into capability gaps and readiness markers, organizations can accelerate their headless adoption journey, improve pipeline planning, and ultimately enhance the quality and predictability of their digital transformation initiatives.  

For more details on the above release features, check out the following resources: 

  • SAP Commerce Cloud Release Ready Kit 
  • Performance Optimization Best Practices 
  • SAP Commerce Cloud update cycle 
  • SAP Commerce Cloud Release Navigator single access point to release content 
  • Sign up for Q4 2025 SAP Commerce Cloud release recap webcast 
  • Replay SAP Commerce Cloud: Year in Review and 2026 Roadmap webcast 

 

SAP Help Portal 

  • SAP Commerce Cloud Whatâ€™s New 

 

Please share your feedback in a comment and follow our SAP Commerce Cloud topic page to connect with the community!

entry.title: Re: How to see Queue errors in SXMB_MONI
entry.content:
Below are the options to identify the error

  • Execute transaction SMQ1 & SMQ2. Look for the queue name related to your interface (often starts with XBQ* or XBT*). If the message is stuck, youâ€™ll see entries with status â€œSYSFAILâ€ or â€œREADY.â€
  • Open the message ID â†’ go to Technical Details â†’ Message Log. Sometimes the error is hidden in the log (e.g., â€œNo COMMIT issued,â€ â€œReceiver channel error,â€ â€œMapping failedâ€).
  • Go to transaction SLG1 with object XMB or XI. Enter the message ID â†’ you may see more detailed error text.
  • If this is not pure ABAP but involves the Adapter Engine, check the Adapter Engine message log in the Integration Engine or NWA. Errors there wonâ€™t show in ST22.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management 2602 Release Key Innovations
entry.content:
1.  Launch Automatic Matching Manually (CIM-2465)

You can now trigger automatic matching directly from the Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally app while editing a draft invoice. With the new "Match Automatically" button, you can quickly validate invoice data against purchase orders or receipts without leaving your workflow.

Once you have chosen Match Automatically, you can determine which line items will be considered when you launch the automatic matching:

  • All items
  • Non-manually assigned items
  • Unassigned items
  • Items with errors

Any existing posting data that is provided for the selected line items will be deleted and recreated through the automatic matching. The supplier invoice will be saved and move to the process step Reference Object Matching.

Example of the User Interface

The screenshot below shows a new Match Automatically button along with the options for automatic matching in the Manage:

Benefits:

  • Saves time: Eliminate the need to navigate between screens to initiate matching.
  • Improves accuracy: Reduce errors by automating the validation process.
  • Boosts efficiency: Speed up invoice approvals with fewer manual steps.

This enhancement helps you to process invoices faster while maintaining compliance and control.

2.  Decision Tables in Configure Assignment Group Rules App (CIM-2861)

Managing invoice assignments just got smarter. With this release, the Configure Assignment Group Rules app now supports Decision Tables, making it easier to define and apply complex routing rules.

When creating a variant in the Configure Assignment Group Rules app, you can now select Decision Table in the Assignment Group/User Rule field within the Step Configuration tab. Below are the available input parameter combinations for different decision tables. Assignment groups and users are the output:

  • Company Code and WBS Element
  • Company Code and Cost Center
  • Company Code, Invoicing Party, and Gross Amount
  • Company Code and G/L Account
  • Commodity Code 

Example of the User Interface

The figure below shows the list of decision tables available in the Configure Decision Tables app for the assignment group and user determination:

Why it matters:

  • Simplified rule configuration:  Decision tables provide a clear, structured way to define assignment rules, reducing manual effort and minimizing errors.
  • Enhanced flexibility:  Use decision tables directly in the Assignment Group/User Rule field under the Step Configuration tab when setting up variants.
  • Improved accuracy:  Ensure invoices are routed to the right teams or users based on predefined conditions, improving processing speed and compliance.

This feature empowers your finance and procurement teams to handle exceptions and approvals more efficiently, reducing bottlenecks and accelerating invoice processing.

3.  Assignment Group/User determined by Custom Logic in the Configure Assignment Group Rules app (CIM-1759)

With this release, it is possible to determine the assignment group or user, or a combination of both, using custom logic.

In the Configure Assignment Group Rules app, you now have the option to choose an assignment group/user rule. This is available in the new Assignment Group/User Rule field in the Step Configuration tab.

If you choose Assignment Group/User Determined by Custom Logic in this field, it allows you to determine the assignment group or user of a step without specifying them during variant creation. The determination is done outside the app via an API.

Example of the User Interface

The screenshot below shows the Step Configuration tab in the Configure Assignment Group Rules app:

4.  Simulation of Workflow Steps before Submission of Invoice (CIM-1759)

The latest release of SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management introduces exciting new features designed to simplify workflows, reduce errors, and improve collaboration between finance teams and suppliers. 

Key Benefits of this Feature:

  • Enhanced Transparency â€“ See the full approval path upfront, so there are no surprises.
  • Proactive Issue Resolution â€“ Spot potential delays or missing approvals before submission.
  • Improved Efficiency â€“ Reduce back-and-forth by ensuring invoices follow the correct workflow from the start.

Changes to the User Interface

The screenshot below shows tab when there is no request for information available and an approval workflow is yet to start:

The next screenshot shows the tab when a request for information has started but an approval workflow is yet to start:

 The final screenshot below shows the tab when all the workflows have started:

This enhancement is just one way weâ€™re making invoice management smarter and more intuitive for our customers.

5.  New Field for Invoice Management (CIM-3034)

A new Contact Person field has been added to the invoice detail page, allowing users to designate a responsible individual for managing and approving invoices. This feature enhances accountability and streamlines the invoice approval process, ensuring timely payments and efficient workflow management.

This field is hidden by default. You can control its visibility using the Configure Business Data Scope app. For more information, see About Field Control. You can use the value help to enter a name in this field.

You can also set the contact person as an approver of an invoice. To do this, select Contact Person for The Invoice in the Agent Determination Rule field of the Step Configuration tab.  This applies when creating a variant or adding a step in an existing variant in the Manage Workflows for Supplier Invoice Approval app.

In addition, you can configure automatic allocation of a supplier invoice to the name entered. To achieve this, select Contact Person for the Invoice in the Assignment Group/User Rule field of the Step Configuration tab. This applies when creating a variant or adding a step in an existing variant in the Configure Assignment Group Rules app.  

A new Contact Person filter is also added to the invoice list page to filter the invoices based on it. This filter and the column are not available by default. See Adapting Filters and Creating Variants for more information on how to show or hide the filters and the columns.  Any update made in this new field is recorded in the activity log.

Changes to the User Interface

The screenshot below shows you the Contact Person field:

Benefits:

  • Enhanced accountability â€“ Designate a specific contact for each invoice, reducing confusion and delays.
  • Streamlined approvals â€“ Faster processing with direct responsibility, leading to timely payments.
  • Improved workflow efficiency â€“ Better tracking and communication for smoother invoice management.

This small but impactful feature helps teams work more effectively, reducing bottlenecks and improving collaboration across finance and procurement teams.

Whatâ€™s Next?

Stay tuned for more innovations in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management as we continue to enhance automation, visibility, and control in your invoice management processes.

Have questions or want to learn more? Reach out to your SAP representative or explore our help documentation at http://help.sap.com.

Letâ€™s make invoice management simpler, smarter, and fasterâ€”together.

Resources:

  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement and Network
  • Whatâ€™s New

Hi everyone,

entry.title: Re: Using different GL to record Receivables
entry.content: You cannot override the recon account at posting time in the Create Outgoing Invoices app; it is always derived from BP master data. Recon accounts are control accounts; they are not meant to be changed frequently. If you need flexibility, consider creating alternative BP master records or using different reconciliation accounts by customer group.

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud: How can I compare variable values?
entry.content:
Hi Nikhil,

The following script works for me:

var cust = Chart_59.getDataSource().getVariableValues("0S_CUS")[0];
var cust_single = cast(Type.SingleVariableValue, cust);
var cust_val = cust_single.value;
var cust_num = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(cust_val);

var border = 10000000;

if (cust_num > border) {
Application.setPageVisible("Page_7", false);
} else {
Application.setPageVisible("Page_7", true);
}

Thanks for your help!

Regards,
Yvonne

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM Observability: Instrumenting SAP NetWeaver Java AS with OpenTelemetry
entry.content:
Instrumenting SAP NetWeaver Java AS with OpenTelemetry

This article focuses on configuring OpenTelemetry for SAP NetWeaver Application Server (AS) Java. For additional stepsâ€”such as registering a service in SAP Cloud ALM, obtaining API credentials, or setting up the OpenTelemetry Collectorâ€”refer to the following blog: observability-for-third-party-components-components-using-sap-cloud-alm.

Prerequisites

Before configuring OpenTelemetry on SAP NetWeaver Java AS:

  1. Download the OpenTelemetry Java Agent.
  2. Copy the agent file to your desired directory.

Steps to Configure via NetWeaver Administrator (NWA)

  1. Access NWA:

    • Open your browser and navigate to: http://<hostname>:<port>/nwa
    • Note: You need administrator privileges to make these changes.

  2. Navigate to Java System Properties:

    • Go to Configuration â†’ Infrastructure â†’ Java System Properties.

  3. Select the Java Server Node:

    • Expand the template name and choose the ID of a Java Server Node.

  4. Add the OpenTelemetry Java Agent:

    • Under Additional VM Parameters, add:
      -javaagent:/<path_to_file>/opentelemetry-javaagent.jar

  5. Configure System VM Parameters:

    • Switch to the System VM Parameters tab and add the following:


      parameter name parameter value
      otel.exporter.otlp.metrics.endpointhttp://demo_otel:4318*
      otel.exporter.otlp.protocolgrpc
      otel.exporter.metrics.exporterotlp
      * - referring to the OTel collector configuration, described on Observability for third party components component... - SAP Community

  6. Repeat for All Java Application Instances:

    • If multiple server nodes exist, specify a unique attribute (e.g., otel.resource.attributes=service.name=JC7-Instance_00).

  7. Save and Restart:

    • Save the settings and restart the system to activate data collection.

  8. Verify Metrics in SAP Cloud ALM:

    • Check the collected metrics in Health Monitoring by selecting the defined "Unspecific Cloud Service" in the scope selector.

 

Collecting OpenTelemetry Logs and Traces

In addition to metrics, you can also collect Java logs and traces, which appear in Integration & Exception Monitoring and Real User Monitoring. To enable this, add the following parameters:

parameter nameparameter value
otel.exporter.logs.exporterotlp
otel.exporter.traces.exporterotlp

Logs & Traces in SAP Cloud ALM

  • Logs: View in Integration & Exception Monitoring.
  • Traces: View in Real User Monitoring.

To view the reported exceptions, launch the Integration & Exception Monitoring.

The request executions and their response times can be analyzed in Real User Monitoring.

 

Conclusion

By following these steps, you can successfully instrument SAP NetWeaver Java AS with OpenTelemetry, enabling comprehensive observability for metrics, logs, and traces in SAP Cloud ALM.

entry.title: Re: Extending SAP SuccessFactors with SAP Build: Building a Global Payroll Dashboard Using ECP Data

entry.title: Error E2023 when changing the table of a projection view via SE11
entry.content:
In my system ABAP 7.58 SP 1, I've created and activated a projection view via SE11, then I want to change the base table to ZXXXX and got the error E2023 "ZXXXX is not active" although the table ZXXXX is active?

I couldn't find a SAP note for that. What's the problem, how to fix it?

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: Error E2023 when changing the table of a projection view via SE11
entry.content:
There's a fix by the SAP note 3558664 - Creation of projection view not possible with SE11 - SAP for Me.

For information, it's mentioned that the bug happens only for the creation, but it happens for the modification too. Also, the SAP note mentions the error text but not its message number E2023.

entry.content:
Hi @KumarNikhil 

If  your badge has not been generated in SAP Learning or on Credly/Badgr after completing a course, it is likely due to a synchronization issue, a delay in processing, or a mismatch in your account details

Here is a troubleshooting guide based on common issues: Digital badges - General FAQ

Kind regards
Margit

entry.title: Creating value in airlines
entry.content:
MOST PROFITABLE, LARGEST, AND MOST VALUABLE ARILINE

As we travel back from the holidays, or into year-start meetings, it may be a good time to reflect on the companies that make such travel possible. In this case, letâ€™s examine Delta Air Linesâ€™ transformation journey with SAP.

Specifically, let us zoom in on three related areas of transformation:
1. Deltaâ€™s strategy of top customer experience, which among other things means on-time flights.
2. Workforce optimization to enable upward mobility for some 100,000 people.
3. Improving financial close, which was historically burdened with significant non-linearity.

These areas of Deltaâ€™s evolution show a clear connection between passenger experience, Deltaâ€™s own resources, and share- and debt-holders as providers of capital.

Letâ€™s start from the customer excellence.
â€ƒ
ON-TIME ARRIVAL
You can see the comparison of Delta with other major global airlines: horizontally plotted are percentages of flights with on-time arrival and vertically plotted are the number of flights per year. Delta, with some of the highest number of flights in the world, is constantly improving its on-time arrival statistics and currently stands at 84%. This is an amazing achievement for such a large operation. The accolades from the media and experts are well deserved.

But letâ€™s look at what it took to achieve such operational excellence.

For now, let us focus on the processes part of the equation; we will talk about people soon.
The major reason for delayed flights, apart from the weather, is supplies. Catering, to be more specific. Before Delta embarked on the journey to significantly overhaul its operations, the state of the union was as follows:

  1. Very large operations across the globeâ€¦ but email communications with the suppliers.
  2. Multiple items of suppliesâ€¦ but some not even recorded in Deltaâ€™s inventory system. For example, there were stories of half a million dollars' worth of earbuds and a million dollars' worth of blankets left in various airports without any visibility for Deltaâ€™s operational colleagues.

That had to change, and Delta did change them. To support its in-sourcing processes, the company adopted SAP IBP and SAP SAC to enable some 155 locations, 255 suppliers and 8 warehouses worldwide.
As a result of demand sensing and inventory optimization, Delta was able to optimize its catering, including the weight aspect of the supplies (for example, the number of food and beverage items based on the passenger count). This, in turn, led do significant fuel savings, which cumulatively accounted for some $100m cost savings in 2024.

To sum it up, for the first strategic transformation area, not only did Delta improve its on-time arrival KPI but it also removed some costs. This brings us to the people side of the equationâ€¦

Workforce mobility
Operational excellence goes hand in hand with the people excellence. Especially when you know that people expenses account for a quarter of your revenue or some $15 billion, and they grow faster than revenues.
The company decided to do a few things:
1. Lower the educational requirements and rather train people on the job.
2. Give people opportunities to advance.
3. Lower the â€œextra shift costsâ€ where possible.

Why this was critical becomes clear when you look at Deltaâ€™s workforceâ€¦
Deltaâ€™s people represent a very diverse human resource organization, by location, type of job performed, and typical challenges.

So let us, together with Delta, look at one typical employeeâ€¦
Like many large organizations, Delta sees two significant workforce drivers: Source & Recruit and Enable & Develop.
Itâ€™s the second one where the company realized it was missing a lot. Meet Eleanor, a typical high-achiever, who â€“ through her effort on the ground â€“ became a top performer (â€œred coatâ€ in Deltaâ€™s language) but wants to push herself even higher. When Eleanor searched the corporate portal for job opportunities in Finance, some 1,100 results appeared â€“ an impossible number to comprehend and take action on. This is what Deltaâ€™s colleagues call the â€œfoggy gapâ€: the desire to learn and grow is present, but no enabler exists for that.

When the managers considered the traditional approach, they quickly realized its limitations and resulting frustration, both for the employees and for the hiring managers.

Therefore, Delta adopted its own, unique approach: FOCUS ON SKILLS, NOT JOB DESCRIPTION.

During the transformation, Delta created a repository of SKILLS making it available to employee and tying skills the Deltaâ€™s HR needs. This enables the employees to focus on what they either have to have to develop, as opposed to searching through numerous job postings and trying to decipher them.  The results of this approach are quite telling.  Half of the managerial positions are filled with experience Delta veterans ensuring upward mobility and job satisfaction, and the central skills repository is easy to maintain and update.

But most important is the overall outcome: employees who feel taken care of by Delta, take good care of the Delta customers.

Now that we have reviewed two strategic initiatives â€“ on time flight arrival and employee mobility â€“ we can look at another challenge Delta faced throughout the years.

 

Nonlinearity
It is January 1. Or April1. Time to close the year or quarter. Yet during this first week of January or April, Delta receives the vast majority of its invoices including from contractors for the previous period. The week is literally flooded with work. For the year close, we are talking about some $30 billion in gross debits! Thatâ€™s half of the total annual business.

Such contracted services come from different sources, including companies such as Unifi, an approximately $2bn and 40,000 employee strong largest provider of air services in North America. (link)

Services such as plane taxying, cleaning, baggage loading, special needs passenger transportation, tie back to the on-time flight departure and arrival as well, so they are critical to Deltaâ€™s strategy...
â€¦and for Delta, such services spell into some $4 billion cost item, i.e., approximately $1bn each quarter.

Before the transformation, most of such reconciliation and postings were manual. To automate this process, Delta utilized SAP HANA as the main source of flight data, coupled it with the AI tools from Blackline, creating a more automatic incoming invoice matching and posting process.

As a result, some 2/3 ds of the accruals became automatic matches, and that trend continues. Overall, this automation significantly lessens the strain of period close and compresses the time to close, freeing oCFO colleaguesâ€™ time for higher added value work.

But the amazing by-product of the automation is a much shorter time to publish quarterly reports. Among the major US airlines, Delta is the fastest to file its 10-Qs, the quarterly reports, therefore improving its stance with the share- and debt-holders.

So, the question is, does the market notice all these Deltaâ€™s efforts to evolve across the three strategic imperatives?

Recap
The answer is unequivocal yes. Through its incredible journey to improve customer service, create workforce mobility, and combat non-linearity for faster financial close, in the past 5 years, Delta grew its Enterprise Value by 1.4x or at approximately 7.6% CAGR. Delta has become one of the most profitable and the most valuable airline.  I am proud to say that SAP has supported Delta in every step.


*    *     *

Big debt of gratitude to my partners at SAP and, most importantly, to Delta â€“ for being an SAP customer!

entry.title: Scripting SAC with DropDown
entry.content:
Hi team,

Iâ€™m facing an issue while creating a form in SAP Analytics Cloud and Iâ€™d appreciate your help.

I have a table and a form.
When I select a row in the table and click a button, I retrieve the selected member and populate several input fields and a dropdown based on the memberâ€™s properties.

The InputFields are filled correctly, but the Dropdown isn't.
The value returned from the member property is not assigned to the dropdown, even though it is not empty.

In the final screenshot, Iâ€™ve added a visual explanation of the issue to make it clearer.

Snipped 1 â€“ Populating the dropdown

Snipped 2 â€“ Selecting a row in the table, clicking the button, and opening a popup that displays the data from the selected row

Here is the code Iâ€™m using:

 

Snipped 1:

Dropdown_31.removeAllItems(); // limpar o dropdown
 
var l_arr11= ArrayUtils.create(Type.string); // array de valores Ãºnicos
var allMembers5_$ = PlanningModel_1.getMembers("CP_DI_Projeto_PD", { limit: 1000 });
 
for (var a = 0; a < allMembers5_$.length; a++) {
    var tipo_projeto =allMembers5_$[a].properties["Tipo_Projeto"];
 
     var id20 = allMembers5_$[a].id;
    if (id20.startsWith("Dummy")) {
        continue;
    }
    // Verifica se o valor existe e ainda nÃ£o foi adicionado
    if (tipo_projeto !== undefined && l_arr11.indexOf(tipo_projeto) === -1) {
console.log(tipo_projeto);
        l_arr11.push(tipo_projeto);
        Dropdown_31.addItem(tipo_projeto);
    }
}

Snipped 2:

 

var selections = Table_4.getSelections();
 
if (selections.length === 0) {
    return;
}
 
var sel = selections[0];
 
var selMeasure = sel[Alias.MeasureDimension];
 
if (selMeasure === undefined) {
 
    var dim = Table_4.getDimensionsOnRows()[0];
    var ds = Table_4.getDataSource();
 
    var member1 = ds.getResultMember(dim, sel);
console.log(member1);
 
    if (member1) {
        var descricao = member1.description;
        var tipoProjeto = member1.properties["CP_DI_Projeto_PD.Tipo_Projeto"];
var Datainicio = member1.properties["CP_DI_Projeto_PD.DataInicio"];
var DataFim = member1.properties["CP_DI_Projeto_PD.DataFim"];
 
        console.log(descricao);
        console.log(tipoProjeto);
 
 
        InputField_23.setValue(descricao);
InputField_25.setValue(Datainicio);
InputField_24.setValue(DataFim);
        Dropdown_29.setSelectedKey(tipoProjeto);
 
    }
}


 


Thank you,

Ganjos

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP - Q4 2025 Innobytes
entry.content:
Happy new year and welcome back to the SAP BTP Innobytes! 2026 is going to be an exciting year and we have big ideas and a strong strategy for the year ahead! In the meantime, letâ€™s see how we finished out last year with some innovative highlights.

Check out the video below and explore the latest features in Application Development, Integration and more. Enjoy watching!

 

 

Data & Analytics

My Metrics

To keep up with the important numbers and data, let me introduce you to your personalized watchlist to keep up with what really matters: My Metrics in SAP Analytics Cloud on SAP BTP.

You can find it via the My Metrics Card on the new Homepage, bringing together performance cards from stories and models into one easy-to-access space with these core areas:

  • Your Metrics to manage cards
  • Detailed Visualization with instant charts and active filters
  • Smart Insights surfacing automated observations

You can create lists from My Metrics page or directly from a story chart: select a data point that you want to track and add it to an existing list or create a new one. You can name the metric and customize suggested comparisons and default visualizations. Itâ€™s now possible to rename, delete, copy or move metrics between different lists. You can Share multiple metrics with tailored permissions and distribute it with different SAC users or teams. 

See these steps in action (starting at 0:09).

Learn more

  • MyMetrics Blog Post

 

App Dev Highlights

Analytical Table with RAP and SAP Fiori

Real-time data analysis tools are essential for decision-making, thatâ€™s why SAP BTP ABAB introduced these powerful features for business users.

By adding the annotation @odata.applySupportedForAggregation: #FULL to your data model, you can now unlock advanced aggregation, grouping, and subtotalling directly in Fiori analytical tables. View real-time summarized business data, group by key fields, and dynamically sort and analyse profitability. This way you can simplify analytics for end users, enabling faster, data-driven decisions.

Watch the demo starting at 1:37 to get more insights.

Learn more

  • Developing Read-Only RAP Analytical Tables

 

SAP Build Extensibility Wizard now available in SAP SuccessFactors

You might already know the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard, supporting developers in process creation and UI extensions directly from Cloud ERP apps. This feature is now also available in SAP SuccessFactors.

In this example we want to simplify the process of requesting personal data from new hires in the onboarding process:

  1. Launch the process variant manager from the SAP SuccessFactors application and select the specific HR process you want to extend.
  2. To let the new hire know, that their data has been accepted, we want to add a step of approval. The wizard will walk you through the familiar steps to set up our extension.
  3. You can jump directly into SAP Build to customize this process.
  4. View the process from the SAP SuccessFactors application, reviewing the new hires and the personal data they have collected.
  5. HR will get a notification in the Task Center Inbox and can select approve, notifying the new hire.

The Extensibility wizard can now practice its magic in SAP SuccessFactors, delivering a better experience for our employees with SAP Build.

To watch this innovation example, start the video at 2:41.

Learn more

  • Extensibility Support
  • Understanding Extensibility
  • Extension types

 

Joule Studio Agent Builder

When it comes to making decisions for your business, transparency and control are essential. AI agents can help speed up the process but building AI agents that are both powerful and enterprise-ready is a challenge. How do you combine development speed with the governance and trust your business demands? 

Describe your business goals to your AI conversational Partner and let Joule build an agent that fits your needs. It automatically discovers tools and connects to external systems through the framework support for MCP. Giving the agent deep business context enables smarter decision-making. The timeline feature gives you full transparency, showing every step of the agent's logic, essential for debugging and governance. 

Start the demo at 4:21 to learn all about the Agent Builder in Joule Studio.

Learn more

  • Joule Studio Learning Series (Blog Post)
  • SAP Learning: Building your first Joule Skill
  • Joule Studio

 

Integration

Local OData API access & SAP HANA support in Edge Integration Cell

When it comes to manage persistence and monitoring in hybrid landscapes, integration is an essential step to make it more flexible.

Edge Integration Cell now supports SAP HANA as both a database and datastore, offering an alternative to PostgreSQL and Redis. If your landscape already runs on HANA, avoid maintaining separate persistence systems by unifying your data layer. One SAP HANA instance can be used for multiple Edge to keep everything consistent and centralized. To ensure the reliability of your integrations even if the cloud connection isnâ€™t available, try the Local OData API access for your Edge runtime. You can retrieve message processing logs, data stores, and other runtime info through local GET APIs.

To use the Local API Access,

  • Activate the API Plan support to the cluster using the ELMO UI
  • Modify the configuration by adding a valid API Virtual Host and an API Virtual Host Key Alias

These settings are also available upon onboarding a new Edge node, allowing a stronger performance and visibility into your integrations. 

Watch this part (starting at 5:36) to get more insights.

Learn more

  • SAP Integration Suite
  • Local OData API Access in Edge Integration Cell Runtimes

 

Security

SAP Key Management Service

SAP Key Management Service (KMS) enables customers to manage encryption keys to business compliance and regulations. Group systems and keys in key configurations according to your requirements.   

The Primary Key is the active one for encryption. The SAP KMS supports Hold Your Own Key (HYOK) and Bring Your Own Key (BYOK) by importing Your Key. Revoke a key at any time by disabling or deleting it, leading to a shutdown of the connected systems, locking the data. When assigned to a KMS tenant, connect the system seamless via the UI. The four-eye-principle secures tasks like connecting a system or a key action.

To see this demo in action, watch the video (starting at 7:04).

 

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU, and we would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

You Might Also Be Interested In

  • SAP BTP Garage: monthly LIVE webinar with hands-on use case walkthroughs and demos.
  • Unlocking SAP BTP: monthly podcast covering all things SAP BTP.

entry.title: Your 2026 Roadmap to Getting Started with ABAP AI and ABAP-1
entry.content:
The era of "Wait and See" for AI in ABAP development is officially over. With the general availability of Joule for Developers (J4D) and the planned availability of ABAP agentic AI frameworks in 2026,  the question isn't if you should use AI, but where you should start. 

The "Start Here" Recommendation:  For 90% of developers, the best starting point is SAP Joule for Developers integrated within ABAP Development Tools (ADT) for Eclipse. In addition you can also experiment with the first versions of ABAP-1 model to analyze and explain code on your own - but be aware that this is currently not for code generation and only for those which want to be independent of J4D. Therefore starting with J4D is the fastest but also the most powerful way to start with ABAP AI.

 
Why should I start with Joule for Developers (J4D)?
  • Contextual Intelligence: Unlike generic LLMs, Joule for Developers is trained on over 250 million lines of proprietary SAP code and is aware of your specific ABAP Cloud context.
  • Itâ€™s Free (For Now): SAP has extended the free promotional period for Joule for Developers until September 2026.
  • Native Skills: It handles predictive code generation (e.g. RAP generation), "Explain" skills for legacy code, and unit test generation directly within your IDE. So it can do way more then ABAP-1 right now.
  • J4D is out of the box integrated in Eclipse ADT.
The Three Paths for ABAP AI Evolution:
1. The Standard Path: Joule for Developers in ADT
  • Best for: Daily coding, documentation, and unit testing.
  • Action: Request access through your administrator (Material #8019124) and activate it in ADT.
2. The Innovation Path: ABAP AI SDK & BTP Free Tier
  • Best for: Building your own AI-powered business applications (e.g., automated invoice processing).
  • Action: Use the SAP BTP Free Tier to access the Generative AI Hub and the ABAP AI SDK to connect your custom ABAP code to external foundation models.
3. The Modernization Path: VS Code with ABAP Cloud
  • Best for: Developers looking for a lightweight, file-based experience or those migrating to S/4HANA Public Cloud.
  • Action: Explore the new ABAP Cloud Extension for VS Code (GA planned for Q2 2026) which features built-in AI assistance powered by an ABAP language server.
Key Takeaway for 2026:
Don't get bogged down trying to "prompt engineer" experimental models like ABAP-1 for production code generation. Instead, leverage Joule for Developers mature "Explain" and "Generate" skills to maintain a Clean Core and accelerate your migration to SAP S/4HANA.

Here you can learn more:

  1. SAP Joule for Developers Expands to Private Cloud: Accelerating ABAP Innovation and Transformation

  2. Step-by-step guide how to activate SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities for your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  3. Joule for Developers (J4D) Setup Guide
  4. SAP BTP Discovery Center (Free Tier Services)
  5. Joule for Developers help (J4D)
  6. ABAP AI SDK Documentation
  7. ABAP-1 Help

entry.title: New feature: How to enforce Multiâ€‘Factor Authentication (MFA) by a Super User - SAP for Me
entry.content:
As a Super Admin, you have two options to enforce MFA, depending on your administrative needs.

Via User List Page

  1. The Customer Super Admin login to Sap for Me and opens the User â€ƒManagement Tool.
  2. Navigates to the User List page.
  3. Searches, filters, and selects one or multiple users.
  4. Enforces Multiâ€‘Factor Authentication (MFA) for the selected users.

Via User Details Page

  1. The Customer Super Admin opens a specific user from the User List.
  2. On the User Details page, enforces MFA for that user.

Once a Super Admin enforces Multiâ€‘Factor Authentication (MFA) for a S-user, the system automatically sends an email notification to the affected user.

The notification:

  • Informs the user that MFA has been enforced by their company administrator
  • Explains why MFA is required
  • Provides clear instructions on the steps the user must take to complete MFA setup

This communication ensures that users are aware of the change in advance and understand the required actions before their next login.

Email notification to user.

Provides notification on MFA enablement and instructions on what steps the user has to take to set it up on their end.

â€ƒThe user is forced to set up MFA method on their next login.

Refer to SAP KBA:

https://me.sap.com/notes/3706192/E

Best wishes

Dragana

entry.title: Accessing Loading step for Outbound Delivery flow in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
We are working on S/4HANA Cloud Starter System (EWM â€“ Public Cloud).
Outbound delivery processing is available and preconfigured for Packing and Goods Issue.

However, we are facing an issue with the Loading step in the outbound flow.

Expected Process Flow:
OBD â†’ Picking â†’ Packing â†’ Loading â†’ Goods Issue
(Picking and Loading to be executed via RF Device)

Issue Observed:

  • Outbound Delivery is created and distributed to EWM successfully

  • Picking and Packing are available

  • Loading step is not triggered / not accessible

  • RF-based Loading is not determined

  • Goods Issue can be posted without explicit Loading


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Accessing Loading step for Outbound Delivery flow in...
entry.content:
• Please confirm whether Loading as a separate step is supported in EWM Public Cloud Starter System. -----Yes, but its only status changing, no WO/WT provided.
  • Please confirm whether RF-based Loading is supported in the Starter system or only in Development/3-System landscapes. -----Yes, but only for ASR. Non-ASR case is not supported, will display a message â€œCan't load goods for deliveries not relevant to Advanced SR. (/SCWM/RF_DE524)â€.
  • Please advise if Loading is implicitly combined with Packing or Goods Issue in Public Cloud. -----No, itâ€™s not combined with packing and goods issue.
  • If Loading is supported, please share the required configuration (SSCUI / settings) to enable:  -----For RF in cloud, should be ASR case with correct freight order and loading point be maintained.
    • Loading step
    • RF Loading execution
  • Use RF / Fiori to create manual warehouse tasks (WTs) for Handling Units (HUs): Yes, RF in Cloud WM supports this. Please refer to logic transaction â€œ05 Internal Processes -> 02 Adhoc WT creationâ€
  • Move picked HUs from storage bins to a dedicated â€œLoadingâ€ bin (custom bin, e.g. LOAD-AREA) :  Yes, RF in Cloud WM supports this. As my understanding this should be a picking process, by configuration it supports to pick HU from bin to load area.
  • Perform Goods Issue (GI) after all HUs are physically staged in the Loading bin:  No, RF doesnâ€™t support GI. Need to do GI in Fiori App.

This would allow warehouse users to perform loading activities operationally (pick â†’ move â†’ stage â†’ GI) even though the â€œLoading by HUâ€ option available in SAP GUI is not present in Public Cloud: I would like to clarify that the WO for picking could have 2 steps/WTs, first one move HU from source bin to resource. Second one move HU from source to loading area. The two steps belong to picking WO. For loading itâ€™s just a status without WO/WT. When warehouse operator moved HU to the truck that means the loading is finished.

 

  1. Whether this RF-based manual WT approach is supported/recommended in Public Cloud: Itâ€™s same question with the first one in above. If so, answer is yes, RF supports to create WT manually. If customer is asking about a scenario or complete business solution for whole outbound processing. About how to use the provided functionality to support their business then this will be another question. I think customer need implementation consultant to support and design the business solution in their system. If the picking provided already satisfy customerâ€™s requirement we recommend the standard picking but not use adhoc WT to replace standard picking. But if provided picking doesnâ€™t satisfy customerâ€™s requirement but adhoc WT creation did then thatâ€™s no problem.
  2. Any SAP-recommended best practices or restrictions for using a â€œLoadingâ€ bin concept without TM : Loading by RF in Cloud WM, only support ASR case. Loading without TM is not supported in RF in Cloud WM. But picking is supported. 
  3. If HU status change at the Loading bin is sufficient before GI in this scenario:  Sorry. This doesnâ€™t seem like a question. But we are sure that picking is mandatory for GI. Loading is not mandatory for GI. Picking completed then GI can proceed.

entry.title: Re: Setting Up PostgreSQL for SAP BTP Development: A Practical Guide
entry.content: A tenant can be lightweight, maybe KBs of data, whereas a HC instance may contain up to 3000 tenants. You save max 3000 database instances. Same for HDI-Containers (but weaker isolation). The HC instance size starts with 16GB/1vCPU. The smaller the instance and the higher the number of tenants the more cost savings you have against multiple database instances. Sure, the workload must fit. I don't know the Postgres pricing in BTP exactly. I could guess that the break-even is reached with approx. 5 tenants in a single HC instance (smallest db size) vs 5 Postgres DB instances (smallest db size) in AWS.  You can try it out comparing HC instance https://hcsizingestimator.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/sap/hana/estimator/index.html  and BTP Postgres https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/viewServices

entry.title: Re: Cannot change Revenue Recognition Key to SPFCSC for C...
entry.content:
Revenue recognition key SPFCSC:
The revenue recognition key works like the SPFC key, but it has a different handling with the status Completed.
Letâ€™s say that a project runs from April 1 to May 31. On June 6, the project is set to Completed. Until project completion, all postings are identical to the SPFC postings. However, by using the revenue recognition key SPFC, the clearing postings would occur in the revenue recognition run in June as this is the month when the project was set to Completed. Using the key SPFCSC, the clearing postings occur in the revenue recognition run in May as this is the month where the project ends, independent of the project status.

Answer to your questions:

  1. Revenue recognition key can be changed anytime during these stages of project/contract  (Project has status â€œin processâ€, and  Contractâ€™s item has status â€œReleasedâ€ ). It is recommended to re-run revenue recognition period end closing run. This run will recalculate revenue on the object based on new revenue recognition key.
    Revenue recognition keys can be change in these EBRR monitor apps:
    - Event-Based Revenue Recognition - Service Documents (F6007)
    - Event-Based Revenue Recognition â€“ Projects (F4767
  2. It is supported to change revenue recognition key on ongoing project, but revenue recognition keys have to be compatible. This means that both keys are from same revenue recognition rule (e.g. COSTPOC) or they can be from different recognition rule in case that they have same definition of usage/GL account pairs. For your case:  keys SPFC and SPFCSC are compatible ( belongs to same assignment rule - COSTPOC).
  3. Key SPFCCM is pre-delivered as â€œHiddenâ€ in EBRR customizing. This means it is not offered in value/search help. You can set this key as visible in below SSCUI.
    • Open App: "Manage your solution" -> Configure your solution
    • Filter: Application area: Finance, Sub Application area: Profitability analysis
    • Select Item: Revenue recognition
    • Select step. 1 :Maintain Settings for Event-Based Revenue Recognition (SSCUI ID 102530)
    • Select Node â€œRecognition Keysâ€ 
    • Change â€œVisibilityâ€ for key SPFCSC to â€œShowâ€

Best Regards,
Jiri Minar
EBRR

entry.title: Re: Setting Up PostgreSQL for SAP BTP Development: A Practical Guide
entry.content:
@Mark_TeichmannFair point. Did some rough estimations.

PostgreSQL Hyperscaler runs ~77 EUR/month minimal (2GB RAM, 1vCPU, 5GB).
HANA Cloud smallest (32GB, 2vCPU, 120GB) is ~632 EUR/month per CU estimator.

Break-even: around 8 apps. Below that, separate PostgreSQL wins. Above that, HANA with HDI containers or DB tenants is cheaper.

But.. all containers share the same compute pool. Fine for light CRUD, but one heavy query affects everyone. Plus, ideally each dev needs their own container - you need to count extra HDI for development.
